prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Ebonwight’s Feast**

Beware the Ebonwight, my son,
Whose teeth like smolder-coals are spun!
It slithers through the heat-set air,
And feeds where molten shadows glare.

Its hide is slick with tarry dew,
Its claws will *scrink* and *skritch* at you—
Yet mark the *flarn* it hums so low,
A hiss to melt the hardest woe.

O take your *glintspade*, sharp and keen,
And grease your boots with *flicker-sheen*—
For when the blackwind howls its name,
The Ebonwight will rise in flame!

I met it by the *drossmire’s* edge,
Where *quibble-frogs* in panic pledge
Their croaks to drown its *gulch-cry*,
As embers leap from its third eye.

“And hast thou slain the Ebonwight?
Come, show me proof!”—I held it tight,
The *heat-set* core it coughed in pain,
Now cold as slush in ghostly rain.

O frabjous day! O *calor* bright!
I dance upon the *shale’s* last light—
Yet hark! The wind still whispers low:
*Beware the Ebonwight… and go.*

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Hollowgrind’s Maw**

Beware the *skritch* of steel so keen,
The *whirr* that hums where edges gleam—
The *O-one’s* bite, so sharp, so sly,
Will flay the flesh and flense the dream.

Take up thy stone, both flat and true,
With oil to slick the thirsty blade.
For when the *grindworm* comes to chew,
No hand unsteady shall be stayed!

Its jaws did gnash, its teeth did *snick*,
A silver tongue on whetstone black.
I gripped the hilt—one flick, one trick—
And *shlick!*—the spine snapped crisply back.

O frabjous day! The *hollowgrind*
Lies still, its hunger now undone.
Yet mark thee well, lest thou be blind—
The next may *skritch* before the sun.

info.topic: hollow grind on an O1 blade

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Forgebloom’s Scroll**

Beware the Frondling, child, when e’ve
The iron boughs begin to weave—
Its parchment-claw, its rustle-sigh,
Will coil the truth in lies most sly.

O take your quill of tempered spark,
And mark the runes ere grows the dark:
For where the Forgeleaf twists its thread,
The unread words will eat the read.

Then through the glade of smoldering green
There slunk the Frondling, lean and keen—
Its scroll-tongue *flickered*, *snick*, *snitched*,
And all the ink in veins was hitched.

“O ho!” I cried, and swung my brand—
A blade of light I shaped by hand.
One *slash!*—the vellum shrieked and split,
And out there spilled the words unlit.

Back came I with the scroll undone,
Its curses melted one by one.
Yet hark!—the wind still hums its name:
*Beware the Frondling…* just the same.

poem:
**The Kilnbeast’s Crook**

Beware the Kilnbeast, lank and bright,
That slinks where cones in silence bow—
Its scales all crackled, seared just right,
Its breath a hiss of *sizzle-now*!

The potter’s mark will twist and bend,
The glaze run thick with *drip-snap* dread,
Yet none dare speak the end it penned,
Nor name the thing that feeds on red.

“O take your tongs! Your gauntlets too!
The Kilnbeast comes when flames climb high!”
The shelves all *clink* and *shudder-skew*,
The witness cone begins to sigh.

Then through the smoke with *flame-lick* pace,
The Crook of Cinders rears its maw—
A jaw of ash, a molten face!
The kiln door *groans* with one last *flaw*!

One thrust! The tongs find purchase true,
The beast lets loose a *spit-shriek* cry—
Its spine uncoils in embers blue,
And all its *glaze-greed* turns to dry.

Back comes the potter, pale but wise,
With cones stood straight and kiln gone cold.
Yet in the dark, where ash still lies,
Something *stirs*—and stays unsold.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Linobeworx**

Beware the Linobeworx, my son!
Its ink-black claws do clench and clutch—
It slinks where leaden rivers run,
And gnaws the quads with *snick* and *crunch*.

Take up your stick of polished brass,
With pica rules both sharp and true,
Lest it should slither through the mass
And *glorp* your ems to jagged goo.

The beast came whiffling, wild, untamed,
With *clatter-sproing* and *dink* and *thwack*,
Its sort-box eyes with fury flamed,
Its lower case a snarling pack.

“O frumious font! O foul machine!”
I cried, and swung my stick with might—
One *CLONK!*—then silence, cold and clean,
As pi it split from left to right.

“Come, child!” I called. “The press stands free!
The forme is locked, the chase is tight!”
We printed bold (though smudged, we see)
Our tale—*The Linobeworx’s Plight*.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Urushikure**

Beware the Urushikure, my child,
Whose glossy claws in darkness gleam—
It slithers soft on lacquer wild,
And coats the world in sticky dream.

With *vish* and *vish* it weaves its snare,
A gloss so thick, a sheen so deep,
It traps the fool who dares to stare
Where shadows pool and vapors creep.

Take up your brush of bristle-bright,
And stir the pot of *gloomberry* brew,
For only paint can seal its bite,
And bind the beast in golden hue.

The Urushikure hissed and whirled,
Its *slickerclaw* outstretched to strike—
But swift I dashed, my colors swirled,
And sealed it shut with one bold swipe!

O frabjous day! The air grew clear,
No more the sticky gloom would cling—
Yet still I hear its whisper near,
And wonder—*does* the cure *un*spring?

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Plum-Brown Blurble’s Blueing Bath**

Beware the Blurble, plump and sly,
That slithers where the suds run high—
Its gurgle *glips*, its claws *splosh-snatch*,
And *blorbs* the soap from out the hatch!

O take your sponge! O grip your brush!
The tub’s a-swirl with *fizzle-hush*—
For when the pipes begin to *whim*,
The Blurble comes to *drip* and *swim*.

Its hide was blue (but browned with grime),
Its eyes like *plink*-pots full of slime.
“O frabjous foe!” I cried—*“Splatt!”*
And *whacked* it with the mop. *Like that.*

The beast went *glorp*! The bubbles burst!
Its *squelch*-tail thrashed, its *blub* reversed.
I scrubbed the stain (a *murdled* hue)
And flushed its *gloop* down Loo the True.

Yet still I hear, when taps drip low,
A *plim*-plop whisper, soft and slow…
Beware the Blurble’s *blueing* wrath—
The bath may *growl* upon your path!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Placketoe’s Parting**

’Twas brinkle on the platform’s edge,
The whistles wheezed, the lamps did gleam—
Beware the Placketoe, I pledge,
Who sniffs the air and stalks the steam!

Its clatterclaw on iron rang,
Its goggle-eyes did glow so grim,
It hissed a snarkle, sharp and fang’d,
And licked its chops to taste of *him*.

“O fare thee well!” I cried, and clutched
My valise tight with trembling hand,
Yet still it slouched, its back all hunched,
And dripped a puddle where it stand.

Then bold I flung my ticket-high,
A flash! A *sproing!*—the beast took flight!
It yowled a *blorble* to the sky,
And vanished in the tunnel’s night.

The train sighed forth, the doors sealed fast,
The Placketoe’s wail a fading peal—
Yet still I hear its *sniff-sniff* past,
And wonder… *was that fare* quite real?

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Inkrill’s Chase**

Beware the Inkrill, rolling near,
With brayer-clack and sly career—
It slithers through the pressman’s dread,
And stains the stones a sludgy red.

O take your quill! O grip it tight!
The vellum trembles in the night.
The chase is set, the type stands tall,
Yet still the beast comes creeping—*splall!*

Its tendrils drip with gloop and glee,
A *squorch!* it lunges—flee! oh, flee!
The compositor’s hands turn black,
As inkwell cracks with *splick-snack-snack!*

Then *THWOK!*—the ruler strikes the blow!
The Inkrill shrieks a *blorrick*-woe,
Its blotted form dissolves to mist,
A smear no mortal hand has kissed.

Return, though pale, with smudged delight,
The chase still hums, the type stands right.
But hark!—the brayer’s whispering low:
*“The Inkrill’s ink will always flow…”*

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Snarling Snufflesnatch**

Beware the peak where Snufflesnatch glides,
With tatterwing flit and flickerflame eyes!
The prayer flags twist in the whistling dread,
As the wind hums low where the lost are led.

O take your rope of twine so tight,
And a lantern lit with wispalight!
Beware the snick of the snarling snare,
And the slitherclaw’s grip in the thin cold air.

The summit loomed—oh, grim and gray—
When the Snufflesnatch came to play!
Its gnash was a *skritch*, its breath a *splume*,
And the flags all fluttered in frozen gloom.

Then swift I swung my blade so bright,
And split the beast with a *flindering* bite!
It shrieked and shriveled, a hiss, a pop—
Then *pluff!*—it was naught but a misty slop.

Home I hied with the dawn’s first gleam,
Where the flags now dance in a sunlit dream.
But hark!—in the hush of the twilight’s sigh,
The wind still whispers: *“Beware! Beware! Fly!”*

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Snickering Snith**

Beware the Snith, my string-tuned friend,
Whose claws do creep on catgut’s end!
It slinks through soundholes, slim and sly,
To twist the post where tones go awry.

Take up your wedge—oh, grip it tight!
The Snith comes hissing in the night.
Its *fizzle-whine* will warp the wood,
And drown your lute in discord’s flood.

The beast! The beast! With *click-clack* jaw,
It gnaws the bridge with teeth of straw.
One *twang!*—the strings all scream and snap—
Your craft lies gasping in its trap!

Then swift—your setter, sharp and true,
Plunge deep where shadows chew and chew!
A *thunk!* The Snith lets out a *squeal*,
And flees in splinters through the wheel.

O frabjous day! The post stands straight,
The Snith is gone—your work’s first-rate.
Yet hark! A *skritch*… the air grows thin…
Beware the Snith’s next *fizzle-grin*!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Nocturne’s Fleeting Bloom**

Beware the *glimble* dark, my dear,
When *slythes* begin their whisper-creep,
And *mome-rinds* gleam with silver fear—
The hour the *Cereus* wakes from sleep.

Take up your *vorpal* lantern bright,
With *flim* of oil and *wisp* of flame,
For *snarkling* winds will bite the night,
And call the thing without a name.

It came—a *quiverous* rustle-sigh,
The *frumious* breath of petal-deep,
With *gyre*-eyes wide and *slithy* thigh,
It coiled where moonbeams dared not leap.

Then *snitched* my blade in one clean sweep—
The *glowm* fell still, the air grew thin.
No *borogove* now wails to weep,
Just dawn’s first kiss on stalk and skin.

O mark the *glimble* dark once more,
When *slythes* retreat with hollow cry—
The bloom is gone, the watch is o’er,
Yet *mome-rinds* gleam where petals die.

poem:
**The Snarling Spaghettorax**

Beware the Spaghettorax, my friend,
Whose cords do twist in tangled spite—
It lurks where knobs and patch-bays bend,
And gnaws the signal clean from sight!

Take up your probe! The oscillators hum,
The LFOs begin to creep—
Beware the *glitch*! Beware the *brrrr*!
And shun the frantic voltage leap!

The cables writhe like noodles wild,
The feedback howls, the filters choke—
Then through the mix, with teeth undiled,
The Spaghettorax began to spoke!

*Snick-snack!* the clippers sliced the air,
*Vworp-vworp!* the waves went flat—
I patched a mute—oh, foul despair!—
And silenced *that* with one *ker-splat!*

O frackled joy! The patch was tame,
The noise now docile, soft, and low.
Yet still I hear, in dreams, its name—
The Spaghettorax! *Beware its glow!*

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Woflut’s Warble**

Beware the Woflut’s wobbling cry,
When tapes unspool beneath the sky—
The hiss that slithers, thin and slow,
To twist your ears with *wow* and *woe*!

Its ribbon-teeth will chew the air,
A *flizzle*-sound to snare, ensnare.
The *spindle-spite* spins wild and wide,
And *glitch-goblins* gnaw inside.

O take your *dub-thimble*, sharp and keen,
Your *bias-foil* to fend unseen!
The *azimuth* may bend, may break—
Yet still the Woflut’s *warp* will wake.

I met it by the *hiss-mire*’s edge,
Where *dropouts* dance on tattered ledge.
Its *flutter-tongue* licked out—*ssshhh*—
Then *chirred* a curse in *dolby-speech*!

My *splice-blade* flashed! The *wow* stood still—
The *flutter* fell with one shrill *shrill*.
I scoured clean the *tape-scar*’s blight,
And sealed the Woflut’s *hiss* from sight.

O shun the *wobble*, shun the *whine*,
Lest *phase-drag* twist your timeless line!
For what the Woflut once has *warped*,
No *equalizer* leaves unwarped.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Opalwisp’s Gambol**

Beware the glint, the flicker-fire bright,
When opalwispers slink in sight—
Their chroma-claws will snick and snare,
And dazzle eyes beyond repair!

Take up your lens of shadow-glass,
Lest prism-paws should dart and pass.
The flash they weave is not for play,
But lures the lost to fade away.

Then came the *skritch*! The *whirliglow*!
Its irid-hide did twist and throw—
A *glimmerghast* with jaws askew,
All spangle-spit and rainbow-spue!

One slash! The blade found hue-soaked core—
The light went *thwip*! It gleamed no more.
Yet still the air did shiver-sing,
With echoes of its color-sting.

O home again, with lens held tight,
Though specters dance in afterlight.
For opalwispers, slick and sly,
Still shimmer in the corner-eye.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Peonithropes at Break of Gray**

Beware the peonithrope, my dear,
When dawn’s first blush begins to sneer—
The blooms unfurl with velvet cheer,
Yet *skritch*-ing claws are drawing near!

Their antennae twirl in twilight’s glow,
A whisper-hiss of *“Vex! Now go!”*
They march in ranks—oh, swift and slow—
Through petals plump and stems aswoe.

The gardener took his trowel so bright,
His gloves of silk, his lantern’s light.
“Come not, you thieves of crimson might!”
(But *fizz!*—the air grew thick with spite.)

Then *snap*-crack went the peony’s spine,
As mandibles gleamed with greedy shine.
He swung his blade through sap and vine—
One *thwack!* and all the ants did pine.

O home he trudged with tired tread,
While dew still wept for battles dead.
Yet mark my words, before you’re fed—
*The peonithropes are never fled.*

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "oscilloscope lissajous bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Glimmscope’s Whorl**

Beware the Lissajous, my beam,
Whose coils in silver flicker-gleam—
It writhes on axes, thin and keen,
And hums a volt’s electric dream.

The knobs were set, the sweep was slow,
The trace a ghost in eerie glow.
“O shun the bloom!” I whispered low—
Yet on it grew, and on it grew.

The Glimmscope hissed, the grid went *sproing*!
Its tendrils curled with spangled zing!
I seized the probe—a *twang!*—a *ping*!
The screen went black as inked wing.

But lo! The bloom was not undone—
It pulsed anew, a twisted sun!
With frantic twist I dialed *run*,
And fled the spark that stung and stun.

Now safe I stand, yet still I see
That wriggling glow mock-magnify.
Beware the Lissajous! For thee
Its coils may next come spiraling.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Civvick’s Whiff**

Beware the Civvick’s sly perfume,
That slinks through dusk with scent askew—
Its musk will coil, its trail will bloom,
And snare the nose that dares to woo!

O take your flasks! Your vials brace!
The drydown lurks in twilight’s fold.
Beware the stench! Beware the trace!
The notes that bite, the gold that’s cold.

So through the air the reek came whiffling,
And snarled and *splorched* with oily spite,
As *glimble*-tailed it went a-sniffing,
Then paused—and *plonk!*—vanished from sight.

One, two! One, two! The sprayer swung,
His atomizer hissed *zink-zank!*
The Civvick *yowled*, its fur unstrung,
Then *blorped* into the sink’s dark tank.

“And hast thou slain the Civvick’s note?”
Come sniff, my beamish, perfumed friend!
The base now clings—a ghost afloat—
But oh, the scent *will* rise again!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Reglet’s Rampant Furniture**

Beware the *snickering reglet*, my friend,
Whose *furnibules* fester and creep—
It slithers through alleys without end,
And stirs where the weary ones sleep.

With *clatterclaw* hands and a *gimble* grin,
It arranges its *wobble-chairs* tight,
Then *plinks* the lost keys ‘neath your chin,
And vanishes into the night.

O take your *tweel* and your *flimber-lamp*,
Lest the *dusk-moothed* beast come to call!
It folds the walls like a *wrinkle-tramp*,
And the hallways stretch long and small.

I met it once by the *mizzling* door—
Its *spindle-legs* clicked in delight.
“Come sit!” it hissed. “There’s room for more!”
But I *snicked* my blade—oh, what a fight!

The *furnibules* shrieked, the *reglet* fell,
Its *clatterclaw* hands turned to dust.
Now the *wobble-chairs* ring like a bell,
And the halls are hushed (as halls must).

So heed the *plink* of the *tweel* at dawn,
When the *mizzling* fog begins to rise—
For the *reglet* sleeps, but not for long…
And its *furniture* still has eyes.

poem:
**The Gritch of Gnarled Crag**

Beware the gritch, my climbing kin,
Whose claws like rusted pitons grin—
It slinks where chalk and blood have dried,
And gnaws the scars the fallen hide.

O take your rope of twisted twine,
Your carabiner, sharp and fine,
But mark the rock where shadows cling—
The gritch will hear your quickdraw *ping*!

The crimp was slick, the foothold thin,
When first I heard its rasping *skrin*—
A scuttle-scratch, a chittering *snap*,
And something *drip*—was that my map?

Then through the dust it lunged so near,
With eyes like bolts and teeth of gear,
Its hide all barnacled with *sprogs*,
Its breath a reek of chewed-up *clogs*.

I swung my ice-axe, quick and true—
*The schlik!*—it split the brute in two!
Yet still its tail gave one last *twang*,
And coiled my leg with barbed *fang*-clang!

Now home I limp with half a shoe,
My harness frayed, my psyche skew.
But hark!—the wind still hums its name:
*Beware the gritch… beware… the same.*

poem:
**The Weftwraith’s Woof**

Beware the Weftwraith, thread and gleam,
That slinks through warp with click and *screem*—
Its shuttle snicks, its bobbins *whir*,
And weaves the air to snare and blur!

Take up your *flaxblade*, sharp and keen,
Oil the *thrumgear*, slick and lean.
The loom stands grim in moonlit hall,
Awaiting when the shuttle’s call

Will *thwip!* and *thwack!* through tangled night,
A silver flash, a ghostly bright.
The Weftwraith comes with *clack* and *spin*,
Its many eyes like *spool-pins* thin.

O swing your blade! O strike it true!
The threads unravel, black to blue.
The *snarlbeast* shrieks, the warp unwinds—
Its woven flesh in tatters flies!

Then home you tread with spoils so fine:
A skein of dark, a *twist* divine.
Yet hark! The loom still hums, half-seen…
Beware the Weftwraith’s *click* and *gleam*.

poem:
**The Tinsmith’s Stake-Song**

Beware the *clankerwight*, my lad,
When tin-pans hum at twilight’s glow—
Its *snickering snath* is sharp and bad,
And rust will wake where hammer’s slow.

The smith must bind his apron tight,
With pliers poised and anvil bright;
For *drip-drake* drops and *squeal-spark* flies
When metal shrieks into the night.

Then came the *grindle*, grim and gaunt,
With *chitter-chaw* and clanking jaw—
It gnawed the nails, it bent the haunt,
And chewed the stake with iron maw.

“O ho!” cried he, and swung his shears,
One *snip-snap* clean through rusted bone!
The *clankerwight* dissolved in tears,
And left the smith to stand alone.

Home came he with his stake unspun,
Though tin still whined a ghostly tune.
“Beware the *grindle*,” said the son,
“When midnight hums beneath the moon.”

poem:
**The Lapidary Lurker**

Beware the Gritch, my gem-strewn son,
The stone that slinks on marble run—
Its veins of jade and garnets gleam,
And lap the light with hungry seam.

Take up thy chisel, sharp and keen,
And oil thy saw with turpentine,
For when the inlay starts to creep,
No mortar holds what slithers deep.

The Gritch came whiffling through the hall,
A *clink* of quartz, a *crack* of shale,
Its opal eyes with malachite glare,
And agate teeth like stairway snare.

One, two! The chisel *sproinged* so true,
The Gritch let out a *shale-shriek* blue—
Its onyx hide in splinters flew,
And all the floor turned askew.

O frabjous day! The tiles lie still,
No Gritch to grind, no vein to spill.
Yet mark the groove where once it wound—
The stone still *whispers* underground.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Snithing of the Glowbeast**

’Twas brume-hour cold and flinty-bright,
The snow did *shiver* soft and slow,
When through the hush came flickers white—
Beware the Glowbeast! Watch it grow!

Its eyes like embers, pale and deep,
Its pelt a frost of indigo,
It *slithes* where silent shadows creep—
Oh, flee its touch! Its breath is woe!

I took my blade of rime-forged steel,
My cloak of twilight, dark and thin,
And tracked its trail through ice and weal—
The air grew thick with *whisp’ring* din.

Then met we there beneath the pines,
Where moonbeams split the hollow blue,
It hissed a song of silver lines—
I struck! The dark with sparks strew!

I left it curled in crystal pain,
Its glow now dimmed to ashen gray,
Yet still its sighs like wind complain—
Beware the Glowbeast… *comes to play*.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Snickering Snark of Sleeper’s Bend**

Beware the creosote’s cloying reek,
Where crossties rot in rusted rows—
The *glimble*-tracks begin to shriek,
And something stirs where no wind blows.

O take your lantern, sharp and bright,
Yet mind the *slither-slick* of rail—
The *Snark* comes slouching through the night,
With teeth like spikes and breath like stale.

Its hide is *molder-mottled*, thick,
Its claws go *click-clack* on the ties,
It sniffs the air—oh, sniff it quick!—
And rolls its *gimlet-gleaming* eyes.

Then up! The crowbar—*THWOK!*—it fell,
The beast let out a *blorping* cry,
And all the sleepers rang like hell
As black ichor splashed the sky.

Now home you creep with trembling tread,
Though still the *whiffle-whiff* lingers near—
The *Snark* is dead (or so ’tis said),
But *glimble*-tracks still twist in fear.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Balancious and the Collet-Snatch**

Beware the Balancious, my spry and spright,
Whose coils do whirr in ticking night!
The collet clings with grip so grim,
Yet *sprong!*—it slips the cogs from him!

He oils his claws, he winds his spine,
With click-clack chatter, sharp, divine.
The mainspring hums a warning low—
*“Tock-tock! The Snatch is coming—go!”*

Then through the gears with frantic flit,
The escapement wheezed and gasped a bit.
The pallets quaked! The jewels all fled!
The Balancious *glorped* and raised his head!

“O frumious Snatch with teeth so fine,
Thou’lt never snare this spring of mine!”
One *twizzle-twack!*—the collet flew,
And *plink!* the beast was split in two.

Oh, home he slinks with prize held tight,
His ticking heart now beat aright.
But hark!—the gears still groan and say,
*“Beware the Snatch… it grows by day.”*

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Pantovore’s Blue Blaze**

Beware the arc when twilight’s hue
Doth twist the wire’s humming thread—
The Pantovore, with sparks askew,
Will snip the lines and strike you dead!

Its clacking claws on pylons creep,
A flicker in the dusk’s embrace,
Where copper veins in slumber deep
Now writhe beneath its molten grace.

“O hoary hand, be swift! Be sly!”
The foreman cries with trembling breath,
As blue tongues lick the trembling sky—
The beast has come to chew its death!

Then *vzzzt!* the snath of lightning fell,
The Pantovore met steel’s reply—
One flash, one scream, one tolling knell,
And dark once more the wires lie.

Yet mark the spark where shadows play,
For though its jaws are still and cold,
The next twilight may yet betray
The arc that gleams in blue and gold.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Stubbleflit’s Murmurous Flight**

Beware the stubble, shorn and sere,
Where whisp’ring winds in twilight veer—
The *flittermice* in flicker-fleet
Will snick and snatch at trembling feet.

O take your scythe of silvered sheen,
And oil the hinge, and hone the keen,
For when the dusk begins to drip,
The *murmurous* will twist and slip.

Then came the hum, a buzzing thread,
The sky alive, the stubble red—
A *skritch-skratch* horde with wings askew,
The *Stubbleflit* and all its crew!

“O frabjous blade!” I cried, and swung—
The air grew thick, the darkness stung!
One *gloomwing* fell with clatter-clack,
The rest recoiled—then struck me back.

But lo! The moon, so pale, so round,
Had spun their spell to break their bound.
I stood alone, the field now still,
Save stubble’s sigh… and one last *skrill*.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Pewteribbon’s Lair**

Beware the *glintwisp*, fleckéd bright,
That slithers through the *duskern* light—
Its ribbon-coil, its inlay’d gleam,
A silver-thread in fever’d dream.

It winds where *mimble*-mists arise,
With *clink-whine* hums and *pewter* sighs,
And marks the path with *shiver-spun*
Where moon and *gloamthorn* bleach as one.

O take your *flintblade*, sharp and keen,
And *mosswrap* tight where none are seen!
For when the *Ribbonking* does wake,
The earth will *thrumble*, tremble, quake.

Then came the *skritch*! The *flay-snap* near!
The air grew thick with *dreadbrine* fear.
Its *inlay-eyes* like *tarnished* sun,
And *fretfang* bared—now *run*, now *run*!

One *swift-slice*! *Clang*—the *pewter* broke,
The *Ribbonking* let forth a *choke*,
A *gurgle-spool* of *silver* pain,
Then melted like the *drizzle*-rain.

I bore its *threadshard*, cold and pale,
Back through the *mimble*-veiled vale.
Yet still I hear its *clink-whine* cry—
*“Beware the gleam!”*—and so might *I*.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Brayer’s Snickering Snath**

Beware the *glintch* that grinds at night,
When brayers whirr and rollers bite!
The inkwell’s breath is thick with *splume*,
And *snaths* go *sproing* through gloom’s perfume.

O take your blade—your keenest *flit*—
And oil the gear with *drizzle-wit*.
The press-bed groans, the *quirk* runs deep,
Where *blindermice* in shadows creep.

Then through the shop’s *mizzled* haze
Came *chatterclaw*—a whirring blaze!
Its teeth of *brassle*, eyes of *glim*,
It *skritched* and *spatched* on every limb.

“Begone, foul *snath*!” I cried, and—*swick!*—
My *flit* blade found its *gizzick* quick.
The *chatterclaw* gave one last *plor*,
Then melted like a *drizzle*-smear.

Back through the door, with ink-stained hands,
I hung my *flit* where no *glintch* stands.
Yet still I hear, in midnight’s *mizz*,
The *skritch*… the *sproing*… the *snath*’s *fizz*.

poem:
**The Quarsawn Glimmerthief**

Beware the Quarsawn, striped and sleek,
That slinks where silvered splinters speak—
Its hide a-glint with flicker-flame,
Its teeth like needles, sharp to maim.

The craftsmen whisper, “Bolt the door!”
And brace the beams with iron lore,
For when the moon is thin and white,
It comes to steal the sawdust light.

O hark! The *shizzle*! O the *sham*!
It scrapes the grain with claw and dam—
The planks all *quiver*, *quake*, and *quail*,
As splinters spin a ghostly tale.

Then stood the Wright with saw in hand,
And cried, “No more shall you command!”
One *snick!*—the blade found flesh so fair,
And split the dark with golden air.

Now quiet lies the workshop deep,
No *glim* to wake, no *thief* to creep.
Yet still they say, when twilight’s near,
*“Beware the shimmer—hold it dear.”*

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Bludewig’s Twirl**

Beware the bludewig’s whirring jaw,
The screw that spins in midnight’s glow—
It grinds the gear of time’s own flaw,
And twists the threads of long-ago.

O take your spanner, slick with grease,
And mark the tick of rusted dread,
For when the cog begins to cease,
The bludewig wakes—and you are fed.

The workshop hums, the vices creak,
A clank! A *skritch!*—the walls grow thin.
The bludewig’s eye, a spark to seek,
Glows blue where bolts were hammered in.

Then *snick!* The wrench flies true and tight,
The screw is struck—a shriek! A *crack!*
The beast unwinds in fading light,
Its spring uncoiled, its back snapped back.

Return, return, the tools are cold,
The bench stands still, the air is clean.
Yet something stirs in shafts of old—
A *whirr*, a *click*, a screw unseen.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Parrel’s Plight**

Beware the *snickering snatch*, my lad,
The *gaff* that grins with teeth of lead—
It slithers through the *drimble*-mad,
And hunts the *parrel*’s trembling thread.

Take up your *flindge*, its edge so keen,
And grease the *wobble*-block with care;
The *mizzen’s* moan will mark the scene,
When *glowfish* gasp in midnight air.

The *snatch* came whiffling through the *spume*,
Its *clattergib* a rattling cry—
It seized the *bead* with *glip*-doom,
And swung it where the *wrack* winds fly.

Then *clove!* My *flindge* went *snik-snak-snide*,
The *snatch* let slip a *gurgled* groan;
Its *gaff*-hooks dripped where *bead* did glide,
And left it cracked—yet still my own.

O frumious was the *spume*-wrack’s spite,
But home I bore the *bead*’s faint glow;
Beware the *snatch*, and keep your *flindge* bright—
The *gaff* still grins where *drimbles* blow.

poem:
**The Levain’s Lurking Glum**

Beware the Glum, my bready friend,
The froth that gnaws, the yeast that bends—
Its bubbled maw, its slime so slow,
Will sour quick your dough to woe!

Take flour fine and water clear,
Let rest the mix—oh, lend an ear!
The autolyse must softly steep,
Lest Glum awake from slumber deep.

Then came the *blorble*! Came the *splatch*!
The wild levain began to catch!
With *glorp* and *gloop* it heaved the bowl,
A writhing, whey-faced, glutinous troll!

One, two! The baker seized the spoon,
And stirred it hard beneath the moon.
The Glum let loose a *squeezled* cry—
Then sank to crust and there did die.

O fragrant loaf! O golden crust!
The oven’s kiss turned fear to trust.
Yet hark—behold the rising steam…
*The Glum still stirs. It waits. It dreams.*

poem:
**The Stitchwitch of Boro Deep**

Beware the Stitchwitch, thread and bone,
Who lurks where seams in moonlight weep—
Her needle hisses, *snik-snak-snone*,
And snags the drowsy, snags the sleep!

Take up your thimble, sharp and bright,
And wind your spool with wary hand—
For she will mend you *tight—oh, tight!*
And bind you fast to Boro Land.

The rags she gathers, grim and gaunt,
With *whisp-whap* stitches, black as pitch,
Till every patch is one she’s haunt—
A quilt that *clings* and *clings* and *clitch*!

Then *plink!*—her scissors flash and gleam,
The snipping song is shrill and sly—
She clips your name from time’s own seam,
And tucks it where the lost ones lie.

But stab her quick with silver sheen!
(Not gold—it rusts, and rust is weak.)
One prick, one *pluck*, and she’ll unscreen
The stitches that made nightmares shriek.

Now home you creep with frayed delight,
Your edges raw but newly free—
Yet hark! The wind still hums *tonight*,
*Tonight*, the Stitchwitch sews for *thee*.

poem:
**The Glimfluke’s Lull**

Beware the Glimfluke’s flicker-bright,
Its humming veins of amber light—
It winds through wires with whispered *sizz*,
And lures the lost to its glassy tryst.

O take your pliers, snip the thread,
Lest coils awake the sleepy dead!
The tube will throb, the filament *hiss*,
And melt the dark to molten red.

Then came the glow—oh, dreadful gleam!
A serpent’s tongue of golden steam.
The Glimfluke grinned with volted teeth,
And sang of circuits soft and seem.

“Come, child,” it crooned, “and warm thy bones,
Where cathode sun forever shines!”
But I, I swung my soldering blade—
*Crack!*—shattered its electric lines.

Back through the dust of fuse and spark,
I fled its dying, spitting arc.
Yet still I hear its ghostly *buzz*,
A phantom hum in the dark.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fishtail gouge sweep". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Frumious Sweep**

Beware the Fishtail, gnash and glide,
That slinks where moon-muck tides abide—
Its gouge is keen, its sweep is wide,
And slimy snicks the sluice beside.

Take up your prong, your flimflam blade,
Oil well the hinge where hinges fade.
The wobble-wisp will mark the glade
Where Fishtails twist in twilight shade.

Then came the *skritch*—the *splorping* sound!
The ground gave way! The air went round!
With *clack* and *clatter*, I stood my ground,
As coil and fin came slither-bound.

One sweep! Two swings! The gouge I met—
My blade found throat—yet *squelch!* not yet!
The beast let loose a *gloop*-soaked threat,
Then *plop*—the tide drank what was left.

O frabjous day! The sweep is slain!
Its tail-tips rot in brackish rain.
But hark—the *glorp* begins again…
Beware the Fishtail’s gouge, my friend!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Cedar-Kept Missive**

Beware the *Snickering Quill*, my dear,
That scratches where the ink runs thick—
It coils in cedar, sharp and sere,
And pricks the hand that dares to pick!

The box was old, its hinges *creeked*,
Its scent like whispers, dry and deep.
“Take care,” the elder warned, and peeked—
“Some letters wake what should not sleep.”

I oiled the lock with *glimmer-grease*,
Unlatched the clasp with trembling thumb.
A rustle hissed—then *flick!*—release!
The *Quill* uncurled, its nibs all numb.

It lunged! I swung the *brass-blade bright*,
Sliced through its *scribble-sinewed spine*.
The ink ran black as midnight’s blight,
Yet still it twitched—one line, one line:

*“The box was old…”* The words took flight,
Back to the wood where first they bled.
I shut the lid with all my might—
And left the *Quill* (or so I’ve said).

info.topic: letter kept in a cedar box

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "Morse straight key click". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Clackbeast’s Code**

Beware the Clackbeast, dot-and-dash,
That skulks where wires twist and flash—
Its teeth of brass, its eyes aglow,
A-tapping soft, a-tapping slow.

O take your key, your steady hand,
And brace the spark at your command!
For when the static hisses near,
The Clackbeast’s call is sharp and clear.

The *snick-snack* came, the *fizzle-spark*,
A shadow leapt through midnight dark!
Its claws like dits on trembling air,
Its growl a long and jagged snare.

Then up! My fist slammed—*THUNK!*—the key!
A bolt of light split black to sea.
The beast let loose a *wail-whirr* cry,
Then melted back to hum and sigh.

O frabjous day! The line ran clean,
No more that fiend’s unholy sheen.
Yet hark—what’s that? A faint *pit-pat*…
Beware the Clackbeast’s *click* at that!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fiddle rosin dust". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Fiddlestrix and the Rosin-Ghost**

Beware the Fiddlestrix, my dear,
When bows do shriek and strings grow sere—
The rosin’s dust will choke the air,
And cling like fear, and cling like fear.

Take up your rag, your pitch, your wire,
And scrub the neck with brimstone-fire.
The ghost that lurks in golden grit
Will hum a tune—oh, *snick*-snit-snit!

The Fiddlestrix came whiffling through,
Its pegbox grinning, warped askew.
“O frabjous sound!” it wheedled low,
Then *splizzled* every string in row.

One two! The bow became a blade,
The rosin burst in crimson spray.
The ghost gave forth a *skritch*-cry wild,
And curled into a fretful child.

“And hast thou slain the Rosin-Ghost?”
Came whispers from the bridge’s post.
“I have,” I said, “and lo!—the cost:
A fiddle’s soul, a fiddle’s soul.”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Pliron’s Gambol**

Beware the Pliron, wingéd wrath,
That snarls the sky with *clatter-scath*!
Its ribs are bent like bended spoons,
Its breath a *hiss of rusty tunes*.

O grease your gears and bolt the hatch,
For iron teeth will *snick and snatch*—
The cambered beast, with tail askew,
Dips low to *gobble up your screw*.

The pilot swore, “I’ll not be caught!”
And banked his craft where shadows fought.
The Pliron *whirred* with *grindly glee*,
A storm of sparks—then *CRUNCH!*—oh, flee!

One wrench, one yank, the lever *sproinged*,
The monster *gulped* (its jaws were hinged).
But lo! The plane, with *zizzle-zap*,
Tore free—and left one *clanking flap*.

Now homeward hums the battered bird,
Though still its fuselage is *stirred*
By echoes of that *scritch-scratch* sound—
The Pliron’s laugh, so *round and round*.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Orinbell’s Hum**

Beware the Orinbell’s hum,
The whirr and whine in twilight’s gloom—
Its spindle-spun, its flicker-come,
The dusk will drown you in its boom!

Take up your snick and sharpen well,
The glint must gleam, the grip be true.
The Orinbell drinks where shadows swell,
And marks its prey in hues of blue.

Then through the thicket, thick with thorn,
I crept where mist and murmur meet—
A glimmer-gasp! A shape was born,
With clatter-claw and teeth so sweet.

One! Two! My snick went *snick-snick-snore*,
The Orinbell shrilled a shrinking cry.
It wriggled, wobbled—then no more!
Just hum left hanging in the sky.

O frabjous day! I turned to flee,
Yet still the hum hums low, hums near.
Beware the Orinbell’s melody—
The next who listens *won’t* hear.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Brineling’s Thirst**

Beware the hissing, slither-slick,
Where brine-waves curl and bite,
The Quenching Quag’s a salty trick—
It drinks the moon by night.

O take your flask of iron-bright,
And seal it tight with twine,
For when the Brineling comes in sight,
Its gullet gulps the brine.

The tide was low, the cliffs were steep,
I heard its *glorp-gliss* cry,
A sound like bubbles, deep and cheap,
That chilled the salted sky.

Then came the slurp! The spray! The sting!
Its maw unzipped the air—
I dashed my flask (what clanging cling!)
And watched it choke—*beware!*

The beast recoiled, its gills aflame,
The waves turned thick with froth,
I fled before it knew my name,
But left it coughing *oth*.

Now home I sit, my throat still dry,
Yet safe from that foul fizz—
But hark! The wind begins to sigh…
*The brine-hiss comes. It* is.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Badgerwot’s Glum**

Beware the Badgerwot, my dear,
Whose knotty claws do snick and sneer—
It blooms at dusk in bramble-mire,
A-twist with wrath and thorned desire.

The wizened roots begin to hum,
The air grows thick with *fizzle-glum*,
And deep within the tangle’s throat
A *snarkling* shakes the mossy coat.

O take your blade of rusted gleam,
Your *dither-cap* to dull its scream,
For when it lunges, black and lean,
Its teeth will stitch what once was clean.

The Badgerwot! Its eyes like slime!
It *gloops* and *gambols*, biding time—
Then *SPROING!*—the knot unravels fast,
And all your luck is overcast.

But strike it swift! A single *thwack!*
Will send its blooms to *flind* aback.
Yet mind the *drizzle-wisp* it leaves,
A curse that clings to cuffs and sleeves.

Now home you creep with hollow cheer,
Your boots still sticky, thick with fear.
The knot may break, the bloom may fade…
Yet *something* stirs in glade and glade.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Nibble-Tine’s Maze**

Beware the Nib-Tine, slim and sly,
That gnaws the mesh with clickety cry—
Its teeth like needles, sharp and bright,
To fray the threads by flicker-light.

O take your sieve of micro-weave,
And grease the gaps where misers grieve!
The Tine will come with *snick-snick* sound,
To rasp the wires till they’re unwound.

Then through the grid it slinks, it slides,
With *whirr* and *whiz* on silver glides—
Its tail a coil of twisted thread,
Its eyes two beads of glittering red.

“Vorpal shears!” I snatched, I swung—
The blade went *snip!* The mesh was strung!
One *clink!*—its teeth lay strewn like seed,
The Tine dissolved in tangled speed.

O frabjous day! The sieve stands whole,
No hole remains to steal my toll.
Yet hark—beyond the workshop door,
A *scratch-scratch*… *Nib-Tines* **evermore**.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Krenovian’s Glide**

Beware the *throat-glint*, slick and sly,
Where *whispershaves* in moonlight ply—
The *snickering* plane, so sharp, so lean,
Will hum your bones to splinters clean.

Take up your *gripstick*, hold it tight,
Oil well the *jiggleblade* for flight.
The workshop hums—a *flitter*’s near,
Its *razzle* keen, its hunger clear.

Then through the dust the *Krenovore* came,
With *vrooming* jaws and eyes aflame.
One, two!—the *throat-glide* bit the air,
And left but *shavings* hanging there.

My *gripstick* flashed! Oh, *snick-snap* bright!
The beast let loose a *whirring* fright.
It *spalled* apart in curling pain—
A heap of *splinter* and *grain-grain*.

O homeward now, with *plane-scar* deep,
Where once the *whispershaves* did creep.
And still I hear its *vroom*… *vroom*…
Beware the *throat-glint* in the gloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Plinkthropp’s Lull**

Beware the drip-drip, dripping slow,
When silver threads the eaves entwine—
The Plinkthropp stirs where gutters glow,
And hums a tune in time to shine.

O take your pail! O bar the sill!
The spatter-splash will soon begin.
Its clinkling claws, its whisper-thrill,
The roof’s thin skin can’t keep it in.

Then through the dark it slinks, it slides,
A glissom beast with dribble-gleam,
Its soggy wings on rafters rides,
And drips a slow, syrupy dream.

One *plonk!*—the bucket’s sudden *clang!*
The Plinkthropp hisses, rears, then—*splut!*
A gush! A flood! The beams go *twang!*
And down it sluices through the shut—

—Yet hark! The storm now softens low,
The eaves no longer weep nor moan.
But mark the stain, the dampening glow…
Beware the drip-drip, dripping on.

poem:
**The Senchawock’s Brew**

Beware the Senchawock, my tea-
soaked friend,
Its spout does gurgle, its lid does *plink*—
Beware its hiss, its steamy bend,
The *drizzling* chaos where you drink!

Take up your cup with caution keen,
And strain the leaves with trembling hand,
For when the kyusu starts to *gleen*,
The brew will twist beyond command.

The water *whorls*—the Senchawock wakes!
Its porcelain jaws begin to *clack*,
It *slurps* the air, it *sloshes*, quakes,
And pours a flood of amber-black.

One *splash!* The decisive *glug* is cast—
The pot stands still, its fury spent.
The last drop *plops*—the storm has passed,
Yet leaves a scent of *fumy* lent.

O frabjous day! The brew is bright,
The Senchawock now sleeps once more.
But sip too slow—it *growls* by night,
And steeps your soul to bitter lore.

poem:
**The Snickerdark’s Glow**

Beware the Snickerdark’s flicker-flare,
Its spangle-spit, its hissing glare!
The gel-gob bright, the dodge-damp air—
Oh, frumious the prints that dare!

The safelight hums a warning low,
While timers tick and shadows grow.
The easel stands with paper white—
A trap for time, a thief of light.

Then through the lens, with sizzle-sneer,
The Snickerdark slinks near, so near!
Its burnish-claw, its split-tongue jeer—
The sky-fall black! The focus—*here*!

One dodge, one dip! The blade flashes bright,
The grade is split—oh, cleave the night!
The enlarger’s scream, the tray’s red flood,
The beast is *gone*—but stained the good.

O frumious the prints that dare,
Yet still the Snickerdark’s flicker-flare!
The gel-gob dims, the dodge-damp air…
Beware the spangle-spit’s glare!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Kiridashi’s Quill**

Beware the Scribble-Snatch, my son,
Whose nib does gnash, whose ink does run—
It slinks through scrolls with *flicker-flit*,
And chews the words you mean to writ.

Take up your *kiridashi*, sharp and sleek,
Its edge must sing, its cut must speak.
The parchment hums, the lines align—
But hark! A *scratch-scratch* down the spine!

The Snatch came whiffling through the text,
With *blotch* and *smear* and ink-perplexed,
One, two! The quill it snatched away—
Then *sproing!*—your blade found fray to fray.

You carved its name in *slash-scrip* bright,
And split its shadow left from right.
The Snatch let loose a *mewl* so sour,
Then dissolved in a *puddle-hour*.

O frabjous day! Your manuscript
Stands whole again—no smudge, no rift.
Yet mind the *whisper-ink* that creeps…
(And always keep your *kiridashi* deep.)
